text: Right. But unless you are literally running a company or other formal organization, as opposed to something like a loosely affiliated network of like-minded people working on the same topics, it is hard to see why people should choose to take their conversations there.
author: kjhealy

text: Relatedly, when I think of what professional societies provide their members, it's very rarely a semi-closed platform for live discussion. Efforts to set those up tend to fail, as conversation more naturally happens either privately in very small groups, or fully in public.
author: kjhealy

text: Yeah that's part of what I mean. If you have 20 people in a working group or whatever and you want/need a private discussion area, Slack is great. But if you find you have 5,000 people, then you are talking about a different sort of community structure.
author: kjhealy

text: Based on my experience of it so far, I find the main issue with this group isn't culture or motive, it's infrastructure. For very small groups, Slack is great. But with thousands of members, it falls over badly. Slack can't swallow or replace the open web.

text: Teatime GSS plot: some people noted the Generational Replacement evident in the last graph. Here's one quick way to bring that out more. People who were 18-25 in 1977 are mostly in their 60s now. Their views on gender roles haven't changed much, collectively speaking, over time.

text: It's tempting to characterize England's early attitude to Australian philosophy by recalling Bernard Williams' remark that Australia was the only place that could have produced that sort of reductive, materialist realism, and also the only place where it was true.
author: kjhealy

text: Absolutely. But Australia was still a backwater, and focused on England, too—thanks in part to people like Smart. There wasn't much of a connection to US networks. Lewis in particular changed all that. As for truth, as a Sociologist I'm professionally obligated to ignore it.
author: kjhealy

text: I don't know off the top of my head. (I'd need to spend some time coding everyone to get a proper answer.) But there are plenty of them. The loop of grad students to US programs and faculty to (Northern) summer visits to Oz provided Australia with a lot of network integration.

text: It's a good question, but not an especially convincing answer. The back-patting about Australian BS-detection is itself BS. PGS does see the main reason, though: they (esp. Smart & Armo) took Lewis seriously early on. This benefitted Aussie philosophy greatly from the 70s onward.
